title: The Northern Quarter's Big Horn to go, replaced by Fred Done flats

An eyecatching scuplture symbolising the Northern Quarter’s difference is to go replaced by 183 apartments built by billionaire bookie Fred Done. 
The Big Horn has sat on the corner of Tib Street and Church Street since 1999 when it was built as a symbol that the area was developing into the city centre’s creative heartland. 
It is a giant trombone structure that snakes around the remains of a red brick mill. 
But the plans for flats, shops and a rooftop garden means it needs to go. 
Scores of objectors complained about the removal of Cornwall artist David Kemp’s sculpture but plans have been approved. Developers assured art fans it will be ‘gifted’ to the city and kept in storage by the council while a new home for it is found. Read More 
Residents said the legendary sculpture signals the gateway to the Northern Quarter and that putting it anywhere else would be pointless. How the site looks now (Photo: Steve Allen) 
Mr Done’s firm Salboy teamed up with Factory Estates for the project. 
The ‘Tibst’ joint-venture scheme has been dubbed ‘Citu NQ’. It is hoped it will help with the continued regeneration of the Northern Quarter and ease pressure on housing. 
The site, currently used for parking for nearly 100 cars, is bounded by Tib Street, Church Street, Joiner Street and Bridgewater Place and is within the Smithfield conservation area. 
It is surrounded by Black Dog Ballroom, the Britannia Sachas Hotel and the Grade II-listed Debenhams building. 
It used to be occupied by a number of buildings, including the Rylands and Co. warehouse, which was demolished in the early 1990s. 
When the site was cleared, a section of wall at the junction of Tib Street and Church Street was kept to mount the Big Horn Sculpture. That will be bulldozed and the sculpture removed. 
The tower block will be between 7 and 10 storeys high and contain 125 two-bed, 48 one-bed, two three-bed, and eight studio apartments. The proposed apartment block on Tib Street 
The seventh floor will boast roof gardens for all residents and the tenth private gardens. 
There will also be space for shops on the ground floor. Read More Bar shut down for 'public protection' after police said it was controlled by a drug dealer 
Bookie magnate and developer Mr Done has set about developing a number of sites in Salford in recent years. 
His plan to demolish the Grade A-listed Black Horse Hotel pub to make way for 400 apartments was given the green-light last year, despite pleas from campaigners to save the historic venue. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
